text:
ALEJANDRA MARTINEZ: So
when I first got to HBS,

you almost think that you
have everything figured out.

And then you get here, and HBS
really forces you to dig deep,

so suddenly everything
that you thought

that you knew about
yourself is getting

brought into question
in a way that

is going to lead to even
a more rewarding future.

RONNIE WIMBERLEY: I'm
suddenly around people

who are not limited by their
context and their environment,

who sort have these
big dreams, and then I

sort of think internally
like, wow, am I, like,
limiting my own dreams?

Am I limiting what it is
that I think I can do?

CLAIRE BRANCH: And when
you're in the classroom having

a dialogue, because
you know everyone

around you, because
you literally

sit with them five hours every
single day, and by the way,

see them at night too, and
you're good friends with them,

it's a really
encouraging atmosphere.

LAILAH THOMPSON: We made
a stand and we started
making a safety culture--

Dialogues and
conversations are fun.

I love going back and
forth with my peers.

And one of our section
norms, we expect

that you think the person
has good intentions,

we attack the idea
but not the person,

not the individual, and just
always assuming the best.

WILL CHAVEY: I think
we'd do much more if we
improve the culture--

HBS has forced me to be more
comfortable making decisions
with insufficient information.

It's forced me to be
less of a perfectionist.

ROBERT STALLARD: You're
also trying to change
the culture of this company--

You really have to think
independently and be

able to vocalize that because
we get to know everybody
on a personal level.

I think that kind of
speaks to the importance

of building relationships
in the business world.

LAUREN BUCHANAN: I have a
text group that is constantly

blowing up with the people of my
discussion group, and all of us
spike on different things.

Somebody saying, hey, can you
come help me with finance?

Hey, can you come help
me with marketing?

And I've been so
touched by how dedicated

other people have been to my
learning and to my success.

RONNIE WIMBERLEY: HBS
is a really unique place

because it's sort of
collecting and directing

the next generation of leaders,
not just in the business space
but far beyond.

I want to be the
kind of a leader who

can bring the vision
and the perspective

but that can also
actually orchestrate
change going forward.

I think I will have
the perspectives

and the philosophies
that undergird those 94
perspectives in the classroom.
